feed.title: Jake Zimmerman | Haskell
feed.subtitle: A collection of blog posts about programming, software, types, programming languages, Sorbet, Vim, Markdown, and more.

entry.title: Profiling in Haskell for a 10x Speedup

link.title: Profiling in Haskell for a 10x Speedup

entry.summary: I wrote up a toy project in Haskell and profiled it to learn about Haskell's profiling tools and about profiling code in general. Profiling in Haskell with Stack is super easy...

entry.title: Lenses & Composition
entry.summary: It's really cool how composition works with lenses!

entry.title: Some Intuition on Lenses
entry.summary: I've been working with lenses on a small project recently, and I thought I'd write up some of my intuition about how they work.

entry.title: ABTs in Haskell
entry.summary: I've been learning and using Haskell on-and-off for the past couple of years. One of my early complaints was that I couldn't find a good library for working with variables and binding that used locally nameless terms. Recently though, I found unbound-generics, which checks all my previously unfilled boxes.

entry.title: Haskell Development with Neovim
entry.summary: After a year and a half of using Haskell on and off, I've finally settled on a set of high-quality development and editor tools, using Stack and Neovim.

entry.title: Troubleshooting Haskell Stack Setup on OS X

link.title: Troubleshooting Haskell Stack Setup on OS X

entry.summary: Stephen Diehl's article "Vim and Haskell in 2016" does a great job of outlining the quickest way to get a quality Haskell development experience. His post presumes Ubuntu; here we presume OS X.
